docs.lead_paragraph: Few students showed up for the first day of school in Gary as hundreds of striking teachers walked picket lines. Negotiators for the Gary Community Schools Corporation and the Gary Teachers Union resumed talks Wednesday night after ending a session late the night before. While school officials predicted a full day of classes in the 16,000-student district, turnout appeared far short of that. Teenagers leaving Gary Westside High School, with an enrollment of about 1,400, said only 6 or 10 adults and 100 students were inside. Teachers, who have not had a contract since December 2004, last staged a strike in 1984. School officials have offered 2 percent salary increases for 2006 and 2007, while teachers’ shares of health insurance premiums would rise to 10 percent from 7 percent.

headline.main: Welfare Reform: Is It a Success? (4 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Welfare Reform: Is It a Success?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Decade After Welfare Overhaul, a Fundamental Shift in Policy and Perception'' (news article, Aug. 21) and ''How We Ended Welfare, Together,'' by Bill Clinton (Op-Ed, Aug. 22), paint a pretty picture of the effects of the 1996 welfare reform. But there is another side of the story. While the number of people and percentage of the population living in poverty did decrease from 1996 to 2000, they steadily increased from 2000 to 2004, and the overall poverty rate (12.7 percent) in 2004 was the same as in 1998.

headline.main: Welfare Reform: Is It a Success?

docs.abstract: Letters on August 21 report on decade of welfare overhaul and former Pres Clinton's August 22 Op-Ed on subject; Prof David S Mason notes increasing numbers of people living in deep poverty; Ellen Bravo says welfare was ended by those who never knew welfare or poverty, like women who used it to stay at home as caregivers; Sue Matorin warns that number of women and children in poverty bodes poorly for breaking generations of dysfunction; Amy Laiken says reform was not about ending poverty but salve for politically manipulated public anger
